subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: Same stupid nasty negative BS!
author: April Abercrombie
full_text:
OMG!!! Seriuosly??!! That has to be the best EVP I have ever heard. I'd say
Class A+

You're talking abotu the girl voice saying "I'm here" right?

On Wed, Jun 9, 2010 at 4:04 PM, tim_woolworth <tim@...> wrote:

>
>
>
> April,
>
> I have received EVP's during ghost box sessions. One thing that bugs me
> about doing sessions is that you can never be sure whether the clear
> communications received are EVP or box related. It has been shown in studies
> that EVP's can be received in a vacuum so even recording a session with
> using the line out may capture EVP's (but probably is much less likely to do
> so).
>
> This clip is from June 2009 at Rolling Hills Asylum. I am sure that this is
> an EVP because it my recorder was set up about 12 feet from the shack hack
> and it was the only recorder from that session to pick up this audio. This
> is a genuine Class A EVP, which is a rare thing.
>
> We were conducting a session and you can hear the cycle through ending and
> starting again. We were just about to end the session and had just called
> for any last minute communications when this clip occurred.
>
> I use Google Chrome as a browser, so and it has problems with attachments.
> According to Chrome, the link is here:
>
>
> http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/files/Tim%20Woolworth/Misc/TW_RH_Xmas_I'm
> Here I'm Here.mp3
>
> If that doesn't work, here is the folder (the only clip in it):
>
> http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/files/Tim%20Woolworth/Misc/
>
> Tim
>
> --- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com <EVP-ITC%40yahoogroups.com>, April
> Abercrombie <april@...> wrote:
> >
> > "Listening to the box is certainly not like listening to an EVP and I
> > personally disagree vehemently with the people out there who call box
> > communications EVP's!"
> >
> > I totally agree. Electronic Voice Phenomena is a completely different
> > animal. That is not to say however that one couldn't get an EVP during a
> > ghost box session.
> >
> > On Wed, Jun 9, 2010 at 3:04 PM, tim_woolworth <tim@...> wrote:
> >
> > >
> > >
> > > So you have stated that the person conducting this study was an EVP
> expert?
> > > That leads me to question how the study was actually conducted.
> Listening to
> > > the box is certainly not like listening to an EVP and I personally
> disagree
> > > vehemently with the people out there who call box communications EVP's!
> > >
> > > In an EVP situation, you are listening closely for a voice to sound
> > > typically over the quiet. A box session forces one to listen through
> the
> > > noise as opposed to the silence.
> > >
> > > Were these sessions recorded and listened back too or was an analysis
> made
> > > strictly from real time? I do sessions all the time and I am lucky if I
> can
> > > pick up 35% of what comes through in real time.
> > >
> > > And finally, try not to be too dismayed. An EVP 'expert' makes their
> bread
> > > and butter parading their EVP techniques. I witnessed one such expert
> who we
> > > all have at least heard of create an EVP. How? The person in question
> > > scratched their thumb nail against the recorders mic to create a sound.
> This
> > > person then played back the recorder to me and pitched it down to make
> what
> > > this person say what was heard sound more convincing.
> > >
> > > If I made my money parading my EVP ability, I would discredit your box
> too.
> > > Why? Because box users are the future of ITC and paranormal research.
> It is
> > > relatively cheap, vastly available, and provides instant gratuity when
> > > operating. Who wants to sit alone in the dark talking to silence when
> you
> > > can hear the responses in real time? EVP is still a valid form of
> > > communication, but ghost boxes threaten an EVP experts way to make
> money.
> > > Boxes are being used more and more, especially on the television shows
> and
> > > public hunts. This hurts the revenue stream for EVP experts who used to
> be
> > > the ones getting invited to guest star on hunts for a fee; they are now
> > > being replaced by box users.
> > >
> > > In short, box use can be discredited by every expert and skeptic in the
> > > field. It doesn't matter. Ghost box use now has its place in paranormal
> > > culture and it is not going to leave it anytime soon. Being situated in
> a
> > > paranormal group that is lead by a para-celebrity has put me in the
> unique
> > > position of visiting other groups and working with the other
> > > para-celebrities in this field quite frequently. I can assure you that
> ghost
> > > boxes aren't going anywhere because the majority of these people have
> at
> > > least a shack hack in their paranormal arsenal.
> > >
> > > So let this expert discredit to his or her's hearts' content. When they
> > > publish their results, the results become public and they are on the
> hook
> > > for what they say at that point (which could bite them in the ass one
> day).
> > > Their results will not hurt the work that you are doing today Frank,
> nor
> > > will what they say influence this forums core group in any way because
> we
> > > know the boxes work.
> > >
> > > Tim
> > > --- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com <EVP-ITC%40yahoogroups.com> <EVP-ITC%
> 40yahoogroups.com>, Frank Sumption
> > > <purplealiengirl@> wrote:
> > > >

> insulting
> > > to
> > > > all of us. As usual, igonore all facts and all other methods, such as
> > > > EVPmaker, which forms all the voices inside the computer. Ignore all
> > > phone
> > > > EVP messages, ignore all voices heard with no electronic aids. Ignore

> they

> > > > successfully.
> > > >

> EVP

> > > > the results have not been good. We have also worked with a variety of

> > > and
> > > > visual forms of ITC are formed and what we know about mediumship, it
> is
> > > > difficult to fit radio-sweep into any established hypothesis. Without

> > > > research supporting it as producing EVP, it is impossible for us to

> > > phenomena,
> > > > we would gladly promote it as an alternative technique.

> voice
> > > is
> > > > formed in the electronics by transforming available audio-frequency
> noise
> > > in
> > > > an active part of the electronics such as a transistor junction. We
> think
> > > > the process is amplification of a weak telekinetic signal via
> stochastic
> > > > resonance and we have found that the optimum audio-frequency signal
> for
> > > this
> > > > is a chaotic one rich in voice-frequencies with many transient
> > > perturbation.
> > > > That is our working hypothesis. "
> > > >
> > > > I can't say who this is from, cuz almost certain I'd get sued.
> There's no
> > > > double blind testing their BS either. Clueless!!
